title: Penny Wong says Barnaby Joyce, Eric Abetz 'offensive'
text:
Senator Penny Wong has has labeled arguments against gay marriage as 'offensive'. Andrew Meares Share on twitter Share on Google Plus by Primrose Riordan Australia's first openly lesbian member of cabinet, Senator Penny Wong, has labelled arguments against gay marriage as "offensive", saying Coalition opponents want to tell her children they are 'not normal'.
On Sunday, Agriculture Minister Barnaby Joyce extended Senator Eric Abetz's Asian century line of argument on the issue, warning our northern neighbours could see Australia as "decadent" if same-sex marriage is legalised.
"There are judgments, whether you like it or not, that are made about us and they see in how we negotiate with them whether they see us as - whether [Asian countries] see us as decadent," he told the ABC .
Mr Joyce then said: "I think in some instances they would" see Australia as decadent if the marriage act was change to accommodate gay couples.
Mr Joyce and his Coalition collegues Senate leader Eric Abetz and Senator Cory Bernardi have led a conservative charge against a cross-party bill to legislate gay marriage which emerged last week.
Senator Abetz suggested it would deny children the 'best start in life' and open a pandora's box leading to polyamory.
'Illogical and offensive' Senator Wong said that the language of the debate "lurches between the illogical and the offensive".
 "This creative one about how Asia will see this, over the weekend; the slippery slope one around polyamory and polygamy...These are people in search of an argument," she said.
She said the language denigrated families.
"I find it sad that senior politicians in this country seem to want to tell my children and children of other same-sex couples that somehow they are not normal," she told the ABC .
She also suggested their stance could impact on the mental health of gay and lesbian youth.
"I always try to think of young people around Australia who might still be struggling with who they are, might be in the process of coming out or having just come out and how it is for them to hear some of the ways in which those who oppose marriage equality debate this issue," she said.
